For every $1 spent on event tickets, it's estimated that $12 of economic activity is generated for area businesses like restaurants and hotels. That's why I co-sponsored the #SaveOurStagesAct and was glad to see it pass in the emergency relief package.

7/7 I believe the COVID bill should have been voted on separately from government funding bills, & going forward, Congress should return to basics & pass individual spending bills instead of massive take it or leave it packages like this. It also should have been done months ago.
6/7 I voted against the rule that allowed this vote to be conducted in this way. I also voted against a similar foreign aid bill in July when the House considered the bill without COVID aid attached.

5/7 Unfortunately, to pass this bill, Pelosi required voting for extraneous annual spending bills that were tied to its passage.  While many provisions in the foreign aid bill were simply wrong, they were attached to the COVID bill passage vote.
4/7 Not passing this bill this week would’ve killed thousands of businesses and tens of thousands of jobs.  And it would’ve led to a shutdown of the government and our military.

3/7 I voted “yes” on the COVID bill to support critically needed Paycheck Protection (PPP) help for small businesses, extending unemployment benefits, and stimulus checks for individuals and families who are struggling financially through no fault of their own.
2/7 Unfortunately, it was the only bill that both parties and both chambers of Congress were able to agree to with inputs from Secretary of the Treasury Mnuchin.

1/7 The combined PPP and annual appropriations bill was a bloated bill that should’ve been negotiated sooner and with more aid to individuals suffering from the economic impacts of Covid. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ep8QocpUwAYzKf0.jpg

It is long past time for Congress to return to regular order and 100 percent transparency with the American people about how their money is spent. END
For too many years, leaders of both parties in Congress have operated behind closed doors – jamming through massive, irresponsible increases in government spending at the 11th hour.

As your representative, I recommit my pledge to fight for responsible spending, government reform, and returning power to where it should reside – with the American people! I will seek out budgetary reforms and real cuts to wasteful or special interest driven expenditures.
This will afford all of us an opportunity to ferret out unnecessary appropriations and reform government. It also means no more omnibus spending bills in the future!

This process and the Speaker’s partisan games are simply unfitting of the People’s House. Moving forward, we must commit to regular order and an appropriations process with 12 separate bills subjected to the amendment process.

President @realDonaldTrump has insinuated that he may veto the legislation unless excessive foreign aid spending is eliminated. I wholeheartedly support the President’s effort to cut needless spending and will encourage Republican House leadership to fight for taxpayers.
This has created some confusion by commingling coronavirus relief with programs like @StateDept funding and foreign aid.

Something that was particularly unseemly was how Speaker Pelosi combined the bipartisan COVID relief package with an enormous continuing appropriations bill that funded a huge number of federal agencies for Fiscal Year 2021, which ends September 30, 2021.

The package we voted on earlier this week is a result of negotiations led by the White House and congressional leadership. We arrived here after months of political stonewalling by Speaker Pelosi and a closed-door process orchestrated by her leadership.

He has instituted a series of arbitrary decrees that have picked winners and losers and harmed many Minnesotans in a number of ways. Governor Walz should immediately relinquish his emergency powers and begin crafting policies with our state legislature.

Of course, the best recipe for the American people is to fully reopen our businesses, schools, and society. I have been a relentless advocate for reopening Minnesota and have not been shy about standing up to Governor Walz.

This can’t be our last relief package—and I will continue to fight with @SenatorMenendez and our @SenateDems colleagues to ensure that we secure more relief for New Jerseyans and American families.

Let’s be clear: more work must be done.
 
We need more state & local funding to support our first responders, educators, essential workers & critical programs.
 
Those out of work need additional unemployment benefits.
 
Struggling families need more robust direct cash payments.

NJ’s transportation network will get a boost too—$40 million for NJ’s airports, $248 million to NJDOT for highways, and @NJTransit will receive well over $1 billion in funding to keep the trains and bus routes moving.

Every New Jerseyan deserves a quality education and safe environment to learn. We fought to secure over $1.2 billion for New Jersey’s K-12 schools, over $500 million for institutions of higher learning, and $179 million to support NJ’s child care providers.

We need to stop the spread of this virus. We fought hard to secure an estimated $100 million for New Jersey vaccine distribution, planning, promotion, monitoring and tracking—and an estimated $500 million for testing and contract tracing.

Small businesses in NJ & across the country need capital now to survive. This bill helps small businesses by extending PPP & providing an additional $284 billion in funding—including $15 billion for live venues, independent theaters & cultural institutions.

The bill provides New Jerseyans with:
✅ An extra $300 a week in UI through March 14, 2021
✅ $591 million in rental assistance prioritized for those most in need
✅ Extends eviction moratorium until January 31, 2021
✅ Increases SNAP benefits

Once the president signs this bill into law, New Jerseyans earning under $75,000 will receive up to $600 & couples earning under $150,000 will receive up to $1,200. You may also receive $600 per child under the age of 17. It’s a start—and we will fight for more.

I pushed, along with @SenatorMenedez, to secure at least $7.2 billion for our state to address the ongoing health and economic crisis. This is just a start—we are committed to passing additional funding bills to help New Jerseyans get through this ongoing crisis.

The emergency package that Congress finally passed this week will provide struggling New Jerseyans & American families with some immediate relief. This is a step in the right direction—but I will continue fighting to ensure this is not the end of our efforts.
